'Robert Mearns Yerkes' (May 26, 1876 â February 3, 1956) was an American
psychologist, ethologist, and primatologist best known for his work in
intelligence testing and in the field of comparative psychology.

Yerkes was a pioneer in the study both of human and primate intelligence and of
the social behavior of gorillas and chimpanzees. Along with John D. Dodson,
Yerkes developed the Yerkes-Dodson law relating arousal to performance.

As time went on, however, Yerkes began to propagate his support for eugenics in
the 1910s and 1920s. His works are largely considered politically incorrect by
modern anthropologists and academics. [http://www2.facinghistory.org/Campus-
/rm.nsf/0/2F63A0AE44B1914585256FFD0007CFC0 "Bio Robert Yerkes"]. Facing History.
Retrieved February 17, 2010. [http://books.google.com/books?id=QP8u1R-

sult&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBcQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=racist&f=false "History of
Physical Anthropology"]. Google Books. Retrieved February 17, 2010.

He also served on the board of trustees of Science Service, now known as Society
for Science & the Public, from 1921-1925.
